summary: For decades, the Department of Energy's Office of Environmental Management has been cleaning up communities contaminated by nuclear weapons production and research. But these efforts have had a history of problems that undermined public trust. The Office has no national guidance for how cleanup sites should engage with stakeholders and governments. Engagement plans at some individual sites may be outdated. And leadership turnover at some...
title: Nuclear Waste Cleanup: Adopting Leading Practices Could Strengthen DOE's Engagement with Stakeholders and Governments
